algorithm_technique: Calculate all pairwise distances, check for two unique positive distances (side and diagonal).
problem_summary_simple: Check if four given points form a valid square.
problem_summary_technical: Calculate squared Euclidean distances between all pairs of points. A valid square has exactly two unique positive distances: side length squared and diagonal length squared (twice the side length squared).
key_insights: The key insight is that in a square, there are only two distinct distances between any pair of points: the side length and the diagonal length.
Calculating squared distances avoids the need for square roots, simplifying calculations and preventing floating-point precision issues.
A valid square must have a non-zero side length, so the distance 0 should not be present in the set of calculated distances.
